importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Initial announcement of the White House ballroom project, including its stated capacity and design goals.
Start of site preparation work, including clearing trees on the south grounds and early demolition activities.
Official start of demolition of part of the East Wing and public announcement of ongoing construction.
Projected completion date of the ballroom project, just before the end of President Trump's term.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline for the construction of the ballroom, including ongoing demolition and expected completion before Trump's term ends.

keyTakeAways: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing to build a $250 million ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission.
The project is being privately funded by Trump and wealthy donors, with no cost to taxpayers, and includes a donation of HVAC systems from Carrier Global Corp.
The ballroom is expected to accommodate 999 people, significantly expanding from its original 650-seat capacity announced in July.
The East Wing, built in 1902 and housing key offices including those of the First Lady, will be temporarily relocated during construction.
The National Capital Planning Commission does not have jurisdiction over demolition or site prep, according to White House staff secretary Will Scharf.
Trump claims the ballroom is necessary due to the limitations of the existing East Room and his desire to host dignitaries without using outdoor pavilions.
The project is considered the largest structural change to the White House since the 1948 addition of the Truman Balcony.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House has begun demolishing part of the East Wing to construct a $250 million, 999-person-capacity ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, the federal body that regulates major renovations to government buildings. President Donald Trump, who announced the project in July, claims the new space is long overdue due to the limitations of the existing East Room and his preference for hosting dignitaries indoors. The demolition has sparked controversy, as the East Wing, built in 1902 and housing key offices including those of the First Lady, will be permanently altered. The White House asserts that site preparation and demolition fall outside the jurisdiction of the NCPC, but the project has proceeded without formal review. Private contributions, including a donation of HVAC systems from Carrier Global Corp., are funding the construction, with no cost to taxpayers. The ballroom, set for completion before Trump’s term ends in January 2029, represents the largest structural change to the White House since the 1948 Truman Balcony addition.
title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom
